title: Cash Converters settles class action for $42.5MILLION after charging the poor 175 per cent interest
text:
Cash Converters has agreed to pay $42.5 million to settle a class action lawsuit affecting about 68,000 Queenslanders who borrowed from the payday lender.

The case alleged the pawnbroker engaged in 'unconscionable conduct' by charging interest rates of more than 175 per cent for six-month loans ranging from $600 to $2000.

The exorbitant interest rates sent thousands of borrowers into a debt spiral, compounding their financial difficulties.

Cash converters has settled a $42.5 million class-action lawsuit affecting about 68,000 Queenslanders who borrowed from the pawnbroker at interest rates of more than 175 per cent

Maurice Blackburn lawyer Miranda Nagy said more than half of the people involved in the case were on low incomes of less than $36,000.

'These type of loans are often a last resort and the type of compensation we have secured for them today is extremely meaningful,' she told News Corp.

The settlement has been named in honour of disability pensioner Sean Lynch, the lead plaintiff in the case fought by law firm Maurice Blackburn on behalf of thousands of people who borrowed from Cash Converters in Queensland between July 30, 2009, and June 30, 2013.

The loans were typically between $600 and $2000 and more than half were taken out by poor people on yearly income of less than $40,000

The first part of the Lynch Settlement, totaling $32.5 million is to be paid within 21 days of settlement, Cash Converters told the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) in a release on Monday, with the remainder to be paid before 30 September next year.

It was argued that Cash Converters had breached Queensland consumer laws, which have a 48 per cent annual cap for consumer credit loans.

As a condition of the deal, Cash Converters did not admit liability.

'Cash Converters is pleased to bring this litigation to a close,' the company told the ASX.

Cash Converters share price jumped as high as 43 per cent on the news before closing the day's trade up 30 per cent at 19.5 cents.
